Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Spatiotemporal Dynamics of Interacting Bacterial Communities in Compact Colonies

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Bacteria are the simplest and most abundant living organisms on our planet, and often exist as complex microbial communities in otherwise homogeneous environment. This project proposes to address the question of how bacterial communities survive, expand, and maintain their diversity. The main goals of this project are to: (1) uncover rules that generate and maintain the complex biochemical and mechanical environment inside growing bacterial colonies, which serve as the fountain that breeds both genetic and ecological diversity; and (2) produce a set of well-tested mathematical models and computational tools for investigating the interplay between activities of individual cells and the collective bacterial behaviors at the community level. The PIs will engage in a number of activities aimed at development of the next generation workforce trained at the intersection of mathematical and biological sciences including the development of a new undergraduate major in mathematical biology at UCSD, development of courses in mathematical biology at UCSD and Bucknell and the training of undergraduate and graduate students in this interdisciplinary area at all 3 collaborating institutions. A series of public lectures on mathematical biology will also be arranged in California State University - Long Beach, a large public university with 43% Hispanic/Latino students.

This project will use a combination of experimentation and multiscale modeling to address the spatiotemporal dynamics of growing compact bacterial colonies on the air-agar interface. Non-extracellular matrix producing bacteria will be used as a simplified experimental system to address the interrelationship of mechanical properties and metabolism on bacterial grown. Cross feeding between multiple bacterial species will be used to explore the impact of bacterial diversity on colony growth. A discrete-continuum 3D simulation model will be developed in this project that will be able to integrate mechanical and metabolic interactions as well as its couple treatment of individual cells and with a continuum description of environmental factors. The results of this project should shed light on the rules that govern bacterial grown and diversity. In addition, the proposed research provides many opportunities and challenges in new mathematical studies on topics ranging from nonlinear partial differential equations, interface dynamics, multiscale modeling, and high performance scientific computing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We investigated the spatiotemproal development of an E. coli colony growing on hard agar surface. Initially, a few such cells grow and divide, quickly forming a thin layer of cells and transitioning into a three-dimensional pancake-shaped bacterial colony which continues to grow for a few days. The cells in the colony consume glucose from agar to grow and divide and produce wastes such as acetate that together with oxygen provide food for the cells to grow aerobically. The cells interact with each other and with the environment, generating strong forces expanding the colony.

Bacterial colonies are model systems of biofilms that are abundant on earth, existing almost everywhere from human guts to soils and to oceans. Understanding the biological principles underlying the structures and development of biofilms has far-reaching impact on our health, environment, and technology, 

Composed of tens of millions of cells in a fluctuating environment, bacterial colonies and biofilms often exhibit remarkably well organized behaviors. For instance, it was established experimentally nearly 60 years ago that after the initial exponential growth an E. coli colony on agar expands in the radial direction with a constant speed. Later, constant expansion and then slow down in the vertical direction were also observed. Our gola was to discover the biological principles that govern such experimentally established behaviors of microbial communities. Specifically, we aimed at understanding why the expansion speed is constant and why the vertical slow down, and how biochemical and mechanical interactions control such growth kinetics.  

We conducted experiments to grow E. coli on hard agar for long hours with physiological conditions and quantified the expansion kinetics, and developed a computational model of such growth. In our model, we track individual cells, their growth, division, and movement which follows from Newton's law of motion. The mechanical forces include the cell-cell colliding elastic forces, frictions between neighboring cells, and the surface tension force exerted on the colony surface. Such an agent-based model of cells is coupled with reaction-diffusion partial differential equations to describe efficiently the dynamic distributions of glucose, oxygen, and acetate in colony and agar, determining the local cell growth rate with different aerobic and anaerobic growth modes.

Our experiment and computer simulations led us to understand the mechanisms of colony expansion kinetics. The constant radial expansion for a long period results from mechanical buckling initiated during the transition to three-dimensional growth and consequent verticalization of interior cells that limit the width of radial expansion zone (the peripheral monolayer of cells). Our simulations with comprehensive metabolic model found that the presence or absence of oxygen makes only a minor difference to the radial expansion speed of E. coli colony on glucose, as neither oxygen nor glucose was depleted in the peripheral region where radial expansion takes place.

The sharp depletion of glucose inside the colony is found to be the primary cause of the vertical slowdown. Such depletion is directly connected to the oxygen depletion, since much more glucose need to be taken up during anaerobic growth. We recognized that the large amount of acetate excreted during anaerobic growth contributed little to colony growth.

Our most significant finding is connecting the slowdown in vertical colony expansion to cell death, the inevitable physiological consequence of prolonged carbon starvation. Our model predicts a localized death zone inside the colony within one to two days of colony development, validated by experiment using two-photon microscopy. Our simulations find that the death zone is localized to the middle of the colony because gluose is available at the bottom (close to the agar) while acetate is available at the top. We find that acetate metabolism plays a key role in cell maintenance at the colony-air interface (the top, where oxygen is available for acetate to be metabolized). Thus, even though acetate contributes minimally to cell growth, it is a key factor keeping the top layers of the colony viable by contributing to cell maintenance. 

What we have uncovered are basic characteristics of growing bacterial colonies revealing a complex pattern of spatiotemporal dynamics that occur presumably in all biofilms since the metabolic processes involved are basic processes governing all heterotrophic bacteria. We thus believe that our approaches and findings represent important first steps towards a systemic quantitative understanding of more complex biofilms. 

The project allowed us to develop additional studies involving spatial termporal patterns formed by colonies of interacting bacteria through their metabolic exchanges, and instabiilty to colony growth due to metabolic waste.

During the project, we trained three graduate students and one postdoc. One of them was an applied mathematics Ph.D. student who conducted experiment, developed model, and performed computer simulations. The students and PIs gave presentations in various meetings and seminars to disseminate our research. Interactions with our collaborators during the project were kept constant and fruitful. The research produced several publications.
